lines.text: Get out! This is a car jack!

[rolls down the window]
Well, of course this is a car. But my name's not Jack. It's Greg.
Put on your Sunday best kids. We're going to Sears!
If Mom and Dad have to sell the house, we'll have to move.
Go to a new school.
Make new friends.
But Jan, you don't have any friends.

[shows Doug her swollen nose]
I suppose you don't want to go out with me now, huh?
Oh, of course I do. It's not your nose I'm after.
I couldn't have put it better myself, Jan. But I'll try anyway.
Marcia, I may be able to use you as a model, but first you'll have to do a little work on yourself.
You mean like walking with a book on my head?
No, I mean like cutting that mousy hair, capping those teeth, and losing about 30 pounds, my little sausage. How do you feel about breast implants?

[slaps him]
Cut my hair?
Marcia, I think I just felt your tongue in my mouth.
It's called a French kiss, Charlie.
Um, Marcia, I gotta go. Uh something suddenly came up.
Hey there, groovy chicks. You're all hip in far out ways.

[suggesting a way to raise money]
I saw a sign at school today for a Search For The Stars contest. First prize is exactly twenty thousand dollars.
Oh sure Jan, like we'd really win.

[suggesting a way to raise money]
I've got it! We could enter that Search For The Stars contest! First prize is twenty thousand dollars!
That's a great idea, Marcia!
Great idea, Marcia!
Am I invisible? Do I not have a voice? I had that idea two days ago!

[disgusted]
Oh come on, Jan.
Sounds like some family misses someone they love very much.
I don't have a family!

Oh, no family. You know, sometimes I'm out here working the graveyard shift, and, I can't help thinking what might have been. If I had settled down early and had kids. Three boys, three girls. Ah, but then a little voice in my head says "are you kidding? They'd probably just treat you like a maid."
[Offering a cup to her]
You want some of this, Jan?
No thanks. You have a little voice in your head, too?
Oh, honey, when you're on the road as long as I am, you've gotta talk to somebody.
As a wise man once said, "Wherever you go, there you are."

[about Marcia]
I live next door to her, and she's harder to get into than a Pearl Jam concert.

[in Jan's thought]
But Jan, you don't have friends. You're just jealous Jan.
[Jan wakes up, holds a pair of scissors like a knife, and starts to cut Marcia's hair]
Jan, what are you doing?
Go back to sleep Cindy!
Jan don't. Marcia's hair is so beautiful.
Exactly. That's why I'm gonna make alot of money when I sell it.
[Jan continues to cut Marcia's hair]
[laughs psychotically]
[Screams]
[Carol and Alice come into the room]
Jan, what are you doing?
[Marcia's got a new hairdo]
Oh Marcia, I love your hair!
What a groovy hairdo!
Oh, you're so beautiful!
No! She was supposed to look bad! No! No!
[Jan wakes up]
What a horrible dream.
[Doug kisses Marcia]
Doug! I think I just felt your tongue in my mouth.
It's called a french kiss.
But I thought you were from Nebraska!
Hey, I heard what you said, Doug, and I'm not gonna let you talk to Marcia like that.
Yeah?
Yeah.
Well, what are you gonna do about it, geek?
I'm gonna lose consciousness.
Wait a minute, I've got something for you.

[rolls her eyes]
Unless it fits on my fingers, I gotta hit the hay.
It better fit, or I'm gonna have to take it back.

[gets excited, closes her eyes and sticks out her hand]
Sam, I thought this day would never come!

[Gives Alice a bowling ball]
When I saw it, I thought it was right up your alley.
I'm bowled over.
Tiger? Tiger? What ever happened to that dog?

[after getting hit in the nose with a ball]
Now I'll never be a teen model.
Marcia did it again. Marcia, Marcia, Marcia!

[in her head]
Let's knock over a 7-Eleven!
[Mrs. Dittmeyer tucks mail into Greg's pants]
My, you've gotten so big. You're almost as big as your daddy.
And I'm still growing.
Right before my very eyes.
I think you're really neato.
[kisses Peter]

[Peter's voice has suddenly dropped an octave]
Why uh, thank you Holly. I think you're Ginger and Mary Ann combined.
Why don't you hop back on the Swiss Miss package where you belong huh?
Okay!

[lisps]
Mom asked me to ask you if there's any mail for us here by mistake.
I don't understand you. What do you want?
Mom asked me to ask you if there's any mail for us here by mistake.
What?
Mom asked me to ask you if there's any mail for us here by mistake.
Nope, not a clue.
She wants the Brady's' mail, Larry!
Thank you, darling! So kind of you to climb out from under your hangover.
Oh those are pretty pictures, what have you modeled for?
Guess.
Are you a Breck girl?
No, Guess Jeans.
Levi's? Wrangler? Osh Kosh B'Gosh?
I think Peter's a babe in a Gilligan sort of way.
[Noreen is in bed with Marcia]
Noreen, is that you?
Oh, sorry, I thought that was my leg.
Marcia, got a minute?
Forget it Doug. Even with a swollen nose, I can still smell a rat.
Jan, come back when you're pregnant.

[her inner voice]
She has every right to be mad; they are her socks. But why does Marcia get all the socks? Why does Marcia get all the trophies? Why does Marcia get all the good drawers?
[out loud]
Yeah, why does Marcia get everything? Marcia, Marcia, Marcia!

[her demonic inner voices]
Watch my head spin! Kill! Kill! Kill!
[out loud]
No, stop it! I can't take it anymore!
[her demonic inner voices]
Ah, shut up you loser!
Jan, cut the crap!
They're gone! Thank you Grandma!
Marcia it looks like rain, you better take your shawl. How about you Doug? Do you have any protection?
Oh, yes ma'am. Assorted colors and textures!
Good for you!
Have fun, kids.
Hey Doug, hows about a little punch?
Excuse me, officers, but I hate to ask a law enforcement official to bend the rules, especially for Penal Code 117, Section 33b, but our house is at stake.

15 every Saturday morning, Mrs. Topping likes to walk through her living room naked. Call me old-fashioned, but these things are important, and they're not for sale. This is our neighborhood, and we're staying.

Cindy, you know by tattling on your friends, you're really just tattling on yourself. By tattling on your friends, you're just telling them that you're a tattletale. Now is that the tale you want to tell?
Why don't you help Alice bake some cookies?
Okay Mommy
[talking to Alice]
Can my doll help too?
As long as it's not Betsy Wetsy. She makes my cookies soggy woggy.
[Talking about the Brady's odd ways]
One time I was over there. One bathroom for nine people? And I never did see a toilet.
Get out!
Steve!
Alone, we can only move buckets. But if we work together, we can drain rivers.
Boy, you sure have some strong thigh muscles Mrs. Whitfield.
How should I put this delicately, Mike? Your designs are from another time.
That's kind of you to say, Mr. Phillips. I've always thought of my style as classic as well.
We'll be so rich you can hire an Eskimo to sit on your face.
Hey Marcia.
I'm not Marcia. I'm Jan.

Jan, a real friend likes you for who you are, not what's on your face. If you judge your friends for passing judgment on you, you're not only judging yourself you're judging your friends for judging you. And that would be using bad judgment.
And that's why I called this meeting.
Greg, what are we going to do?
Yeah, if we don't raise $20,000 in one week, we'll have to move.
And go to a new school.
And make new friends.
But Jan, you don't have any friends.
Hey, mom always said don't play ball in the house.
